sen.j: 手締め（てじめ）とは日本の風習の一つで、物事が無事に終わったことを祝って、その関係者が掛け声とともにリズムを合わせて打つ手拍子。
sen.e: Tejime is a Japanese custom, which is hand clapping with certain call and rhythm, done by people concerned to certain matters, celebrating the conclusion of the matter without any major troubles.
Tejime is a Japanese custom of rhythmic hand clapping performed in time with the calls of one participant in order to celebrate the fact that an event has concluded without trouble.
Tejime is a Japanese custom of rhythmic hand clapping performed in time with the calls of one participant in order to celebrate the fact that an event has concluded without trouble.

sen.j: 手打ちともいう。
祭りや冠婚葬祭などの式典、商談や株主総会などの終わりに行われる。
sen.e: It is done at the end of festivals, ceremonial occasions, business discussions, general meetings of stockholders, and so on.
It is done at the end of events including festivals, ceremonial occasions, business discussions and general shareholders meetings.
It is done at the end of events including festivals, ceremonial occasions, business discussions and general shareholders meetings.

sen.j: 手締めの音は「シャンシャン」と表現される。
sen.e: The sound of tejime is expressed 'shan shan.'
The sound of tejime is expressed 'shan shan.'
The sound of tejime is expressed 'shan shan.'

sen.j: 特に質疑応答もなく短時間で終了する株主総会は、参加者は手締めしかしないということで「シャンシャン総会」と揶揄される。
sen.e: A general meeting of stockholders ending in short time, without any special questions and answers, are ridiculed as 'shan shan sokai' (shan shan meeting), since the participants only do tejime.

A general meeting of stockholders ending in a short time without any particular questions and answers is ridiculed as a 'shan shan sokai' (shan shan meeting), since the participants have done nothing but performed tejime.

A general meeting of stockholders ending in a short time without any particular questions and answers is ridiculed as a 'shan shan sokai' (shan shan meeting), since the participants have done nothing but performed tejime.

sen.j: 「手打ちによって締める」が語源である。
sen.e: The origin of the word is 'concluding with handclaps.'
The origin of the word 'tejime' is 'to conclude with the clapping of hands.'
The origin of the word 'tejime' is 'to conclude with the clapping of hands.'

sen.j: なお、関西では「手締め」のことを「手打ち」と表現する。
sen.e: Further, in Kansai region, 'tejime' is expressed as 'teuchi.'
In Kansai region, 'tejime' is referred to as 'teuchi.'
In Kansai region, 'tejime' is referred to as 'teuchi.'

sen.j: 手締めの主旨は、行事を取り仕切った者が、行事が無事に終了したことを協力者に感謝することである。
sen.e: The point of tejime is a thanks from the host of occasion to supporters about the success of the occasion.
The main reason for performing tejime is as a thanks from the host to the participants for making the occasion a success.
The main reason for performing tejime is as a thanks from the host to the participants for making the occasion a success.

sen.j: そのため、来賓の場合、仮に音頭を取ることを依頼されたとしても、断ることが筋である。
sen.e: Because of that, if a person is a guest, it is proper for the person to decline to join tejime, even if the person was requested.
It is for this reason that it is proper for a guest to decline if requested to lead the tejime.
It is for this reason that it is proper for a guest to decline if requested to lead the tejime.

sen.j: 江戸締め
手締めは地方により、そのリズムや回数、掛け声が異なる。
sen.e: Tejime has different rhythms, numbers of clapping, and callings in each regions.
Tejime consists of different rhythms, numbers of claps and calls depending on the region.
Tejime consists of different rhythms, numbers of claps and calls depending on the region.

sen.j: 大きく分けて江戸締めと大阪締めに分けられる。
sen.e: It is generally divided into Edojime and Osakajime.
Variations are generally divided into Edo-jime and Osaka-jime.
Variations are generally divided into Edo-jime and Osaka-jime.

sen.j: 中でも、江戸締めは全国的に広く行われ、最も基本的な手締めの形態である。
sen.e: Especially, Edojime is held broadly throughout the country, and is the most fundamental form of tejime.
Of these, Edo-jime is widely used throughout the country and the most fundamental form of tejime.
Of these, Edo-jime is widely used throughout the country and the most fundamental form of tejime.

sen.j: 江戸締めには一本締めと三本締めがある。
sen.e: There are ipponjime and sanbonjime in Edojime.
Edo-jime consists of ippon-jime and sanbon-jime.
Edo-jime consists of ippon-jime and sanbon-jime.

sen.j: 拍数の「3回・3回・3回・1回」は3回の拍が3回で九になり、もう1回手を打つと九に点が打たれて「丸」になり、「丸く納まる」の意味になるからとも言われている。
sen.e: It is said that the reason for the number of the beat '3-3-3-1' is because that 3times the 3 beats become '九' (9), and if 1 more beat is added, a point will be added to 9 and becomes '丸' (circle), which has a meaning 'settling down without troubles.'

It is said that a sequence of three claps followed by one final clap (3-3-3-1) are used because 3+3+3=9 (九 in Japanese) and the addition of an extra clap makes a circle (丸) which signifies 'maruku osamaru' (lit. to be settled amicably).

It is said that a sequence of three claps followed by one final clap (3-3-3-1) are used because 3+3+3=9 (九 in Japanese) and the addition of an extra clap makes a circle (丸) which signifies 'maruku osamaru' (lit. to be settled amicably).

sen.j: また、はじめと間に「イヨー」「ヨッ」「もう一丁」などと掛け声をかけ、最後に拍手する。
sen.e: Also, there is a call such as 'iyoo,' 'yo,' and 'mouichho' at the beginning, and at last, there will be a normal hand clapping.
Calls such as 'iyoo,' 'yo,' and 'mouichho' are made before clapping and between clapping sequences before a final clapping sequence.
Calls such as 'iyoo,' 'yo,' and 'mouichho' are made before clapping and between clapping sequences before a final clapping sequence.

sen.j: 「イヨー」は「祝おう」が転じたものとされる。
sen.e: Iyoo' is said to have changed from 'iwaou' (let us celebrate).
Iyoo' is said to have derived from 'iwaou' (lit. let us celebrate).
The call 'iyoo' is said to have derived from 'iwaou' (lit. let us celebrate).
sen.cmt: 文頭に翻訳を追加しました。

sen.j: 一本締め
3回・3回・3回・1回手を打つ
sen.e: Clap hand 3 times, 3 times, 3times, and 1 time.
Three sets of three claps and one final clap (3-3-3-1).
Three sets of three claps and one final clap (3-3-3-1).

sen.j: 一丁締め
一本締めの変形として1回だけ手を打つ一丁締めもある。
sen.e: As a variation of ipponjime there is also icchojime, clapping hand only once.
As a variation of ippon-jime there is also the iccho-jime variation which consists of a single clap.
As a variation of ippon-jime there is also the iccho-jime variation which consists of a single clap.

sen.j: これは「一本締め」と混同されるが、一丁締めは略式の手締めである。
sen.e: This is sometimes confused with 'ipponjime,' but is an abbreviated form of tejime.
This is sometimes confused with 'ippon-jime,' but is a simplified form of tejime.
This is sometimes confused with 'ippon-jime,' but is a simplified form of tejime.

sen.j: 関東一本締めと呼ぶ人もいるが手締めの「一丁締め」を知らなく、混同している方が多い。
sen.e: Some people call it Kanto ipponjime, but most of them are confused with 'icchojime,' since they don't know it.
Some people call it 'Kanto ippon-jime' but there are many who are unaware of 'iccho-jime' confuse the two.
Some people call it 'Kanto ippon-jime' but there are many who are unaware of 'iccho-jime' and confuse the two.

sen.j: 西日本では大阪締めが広く行われるほか、各地に独自の手締めが行われている。
sen.e: In Western Japan, Osakajime is broadly held, and individual tejime is held at each regions, also.
In addition to Osaka-jime which is widely performed in western Japan, different regions each have their own tejime variations.
In addition to Osaka-jime which is widely performed in western Japan, different regions each have their own tejime variations.

sen.j: 大阪締め
大阪締めは大阪を中心に行われている手締めである。
sen.e: Osakajime is tejime held mainly in Osaka.
Osaka-jime is the tejime variation mainly performed in Osaka.
Osaka-jime is the tejime variation mainly performed in Osaka.

博多手一本
福岡県福岡市の博多では、博多手一本と呼ばれる独自の手締めが行われる。
sen.e: In Hakata in Fukuoka City, Fukuoka Prefecture, original tejime called Hakatateippon is conducted.
In Hakata in Fukuoka City, Fukuoka Prefecture, an specific form of tejime called 'Hakata Teippon' is conducted.
In Hakata City in Fukuoka City, Fukuoka Prefecture, a specific form of tejime called 'Hakata Teippon' is conducted.

sen.j: 博多祇園山笠で行われるほか、福岡証券取引所の大発会・大納会、公私の式典、商談の成立などで行われる。
sen.e: It is done in Hakata Gion Yamagasa summer festival, along with in grand opening and closing ceremonies in Fukuoka Stock Exchange, public and private ceremonies, conclusion of business deals, and so on.

It is performed at the Hakata Gion Yamagasa summer festival, as well events including the grand opening and closing ceremonies of the Fukuoka Stock Exchange, public and private ceremonies, and the conclusion of business deals.

It is performed at the Hakata Gion Yamagasa summer festival, as well events including the grand opening and closing ceremonies of the Fukuoka Stock Exchange, public and private ceremonies, and the conclusion of business deals.

sen.j: 手一本には、後日異議を唱えないという含意がある。
sen.e: There is a meaning that there will be no objections in later days included in this teippon.
Teippon has the implication that no subsequent objections will be raised.
Teippon has the implication that no subsequent objections will be raised.

sen.j: 「まひとつしょ」は「もひとつ」、「祝うて三度」は「よーてさんど」あるいは「よてさん」とも発音する。
sen.e: Mahitotsusho' is sometimes pronounced 'mohitotsu,' and 'iwoutesando' is sometimes pronounced 'yotesando' or 'yotesan.'
Mahitotsusho' is sometimes pronounced 'mohitotsu,' and 'iwoutesando' is sometimes pronounced 'yotesando' or 'yotesan.'

sen.j: 伊達の一本締め
伊達政宗ゆかりの手締めも存在する。
sen.e: There is also tejime related to Masamune DATE.
There is also tejime related to Masamune DATE.
There is also tejime related to Masamune DATE.

sen.j: この手締めは「三国一の武将」たらんとする政宗の夢の実現の祈願を込め、「三国一」の三と一を掛けたものであり、家臣団の間で、いつからか会席においてこの手締めが行われるようになった。
sen.e: This tejime was started to be held without anyone noticing among the vassals in meetings, with a meaning of prayers for realization of Masamune's dream to become 'sangokuichi no busho' (best military commander in world), having form of 3 and 1 in 'sangokuichi' (三国一).

This tejime was started to be held without anyone noticing among the vassals in meetings, with a meaning of prayers for realization of Masamune's dream to become 'sangokuichi no busho' (best military commander in world), having form of 3 and 1 in 'sangokuichi' (三国一).

To fulfill Masamune's dream to become a 'sangokuichi no busho' (literally, "the best military commander in the three provinces"), this tejime, having the form of three and one (meaning three provinces and one commander), naturally began to be performed among his vassals at meetings.

sen.j: 政宗の長女・五六八姫の婚礼や、慶長18年（1613年）の支倉常長をはじめとする「慶長遣欧使節」の出帆のときもこの手締めが行われたといわれている。
sen.e: It is said that this tejime was held in wedding ceremony for the first daughter of Masamune, Princess Iroha, and in departure of 'Keicho era mission to Europe,' starting with Tsunenaga HASEKURA, in 1613.

It is said that this tejime was held in wedding ceremony for the first daughter of Masamune, Princess Iroha, and in departure of 'Keicho era mission to Europe,' starting with Tsunenaga HASEKURA, in 1613.

It is said that this tejime was performed at the wedding ceremony of the first daughter of Masamune, Princess Iroha, and also at the departure of 'Keicho era mission to Europe,' in which people such as Tsunenaga HASEKURA joined, in 1613.

sen.j: 江戸時代以降は、そのいわれから幕府に遠慮して公には行われなくなり、宮城県松島町の「円通院」に代々伝承された。
sen.e: In and after the Edo period, from the meaning of it, it became not to be held in public for refrain against the bakufu, and was succeeded in generations in 'Entsu-in Temple' in Matsushima Town, Miyagi Prefecture.

In and after the Edo period, from the meaning of it, it became not to be held in public for refrain against the bakufu, and was succeeded in generations in 'Entsu-in Temple' in Matsushima Town, Miyagi Prefecture.

In and after the Edo period, from the meaning of it, it became not to be performed in public out of consideration for the bakufu, and was passed down for generations by 'Entsu-in Temple' in Matsushima-cho, Miyagi Prefecture.

sen.j: 現在では仙台市内において「仙臺すずめ踊り」の祭連を中心に普及が始まっている。
sen.e: In present days, it is becoming popular mainly among the people concerning in Sendai Suzume Odori (Sendai sparrow dance) in Sendai City.
It is now starting to become popular in Sendai City among practitioners of the Sendai Suzume Odori (Sendai sparrow dance).
It is now starting to become popular in Sendai City among practitioners of the 'Sendai Suzume Odori' (Sendai sparrow dance).

sen.j: その他
西関東の東京都多摩地区の西部（旧西多摩郡）、埼玉県西部（旧入間郡・旧秩父郡・旧比企郡・旧児玉郡等）、群馬県西部（旧多野郡・旧甘楽郡）の地域にも独自の手締めが行われる。
sen.e: There also are original tejime held in districts such as western part of Tama District in Tokyo Prefecture in western Kanto Region (former Nishitama district), western Saitama Prefecture (former Iruma, Chichibu, Hiki, and Kodama districts), and western Gunma Prefecture (former Tano and Kanra districts).

Unique forms of tejime are also performed in the western part of Tama District in Tokyo Prefecture in western Kanto Region (former Nishitama district), western Saitama Prefecture (former Iruma, Chichibu, Hiki, and Kodama districts), and western Gunma Prefecture (former Tano and Kanra districts).

Unique forms of tejime are also performed in the western part of Tama district in Tokyo in western Kanto region (former Nishitama district), western Saitama Prefecture (former Iruma, Chichibu, Hiki, and Kodama districts), and western Gunma Prefecture (former Tano and Kanra districts).
